channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: U.S. and Russia Agree on Pact to Defuse Ukraine Crisis
item.description: The foreign ministers of the United States, Russia, Ukraine and European Union reached an agreement in Geneva after more than five hours of talks.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry spoke with his Russian counterpart, Sergey V. Lavrov, in Geneva on Thursday at the start of a meeting on the continuing situation in Ukraine.

item.title: Nigerians Search Unsafe Forest for Abducted Girls
item.description: Able-bodied men from the Nigerian town of Chibok have taken to the dangerous Sambisa Forest to search for more than 100 abducted girls and young women whom the military claimed to have freed from their Islamic extremist kidnappers, an education official said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: The Lede: Video of Snowden Asking Putin About Surveillance
item.description: The former National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden asked President Vladimir V. Putin a question during a call-in program on Russian television.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: Edward Snowden's appearance, via video message, on Russian state television on Thursday.

item.title: Gabriel García Márquez, Conjurer of Literary Magic, Dies at 87
item.description: Mr. García Márquez, a Colombian who received the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1982, wrote fiction rooted in a mythical Latin American landscape of his own creation.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN KANDELL

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: An Internet ‘Big V’ Opts for Abject Contrition
item.description: China releases Charles Xue, an American businessman highly visible on Chinese microblogs who was detained in August on sex charges. He then appeared in state-run media endorsing the authorities’ treatment of him.
item.category: Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Charles Xue, at the China Internet Conference in Beijing on Aug. 13, 2013.

item.title: One-Fifth of China’s Farmland Is Polluted, State Study Finds
item.description: Rapid industrialization, agricultural mismanagement and metals production are all contributing to contamination that is raising alarms about food and physical health.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: How Near Is the End? Britain May Tell Retirees
item.description: “No point being all British and coy about it,” said the pensions minister, Steve Webb, who said an idea of life expectancy can aid financial planning.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Kenya’s Wide Net Against Terror Sweeps Up Refugees
item.description: Thousands of undocumented refugees, immigrants and Kenyan citizens have been arrested, with a sprawling stadium in Nairobi turned into a police station to hold large numbers of them.
item.dc:creator: By ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH
item.media:description: A policeman stands guard as suspected Somali illegal migrants and refugees arrested in a swoop are processed for deportation at a holding station in Nairobi, Kenya.

item.title: Pistorius Trial Adjourns With Key Witness in Doubt
item.description: The trial of Oscar Pistorius, the double-amputee track star accused of murdering his girlfriend, adjourned amid reports that a defense witness will not take the stand.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Text of Joint Diplomatic Statement on Ukraine
item.description: The United States, European Union, Russia and Ukraine, meeting in Geneva, issued a joint statement agreeing to “de-escalate tensions” in Ukraine.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: April 17
item.description: Admiral Robin K. Dhowan, is appointed as the new chief of the Indian Navy.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Admiral Robin K. Dhowan, second from left, the new Indian naval chief, inspecting his guard of honor in New Delhi.

item.title: Arab-Israeli Activist Is Moved to House Arrest
item.description: The Israeli citizen, a Palestinian rights activist, was detained after a visit to Lebanon, on suspicion of an unauthorized visit to an enemy state.
item.category: Adalah, The Legal Center for Arab Minority Rights in Israel
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Oil Slick in Indian Ocean Not From Missing Jet, Tests Find
item.description: The authorities looking for the missing Malaysia Airlines jet said an oil sample from the search area was not engine oil or hydraulic fluid from an aircraft.
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: India Ink: Bangalore’s Enthusiastic Young Voters Reflect New Kind of Politics
item.description: Candidates in this year’s elections have been eager to be perceived as presentable, articulate, performance-oriented and of significance in their parties.
item.dc:creator: By SARITHA RAI
item.media:description: A woman showing her thumb marked with indelible election ink after voting in Bangalore, Karnataka, on Thursday.

item.title: Taliban Say They Killed 7 Afghan Police Officers
item.description: The authorities in Wardak Province said they had reports that a dozen officers had been kidnapped by insurgents while traveling to Kabul to collect their salaries.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED and ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Survivors of Korean Ferry Recall a Sharp Turn, Then Chaos
item.description: As families suffered an agonizing wait for information on missing loved ones, passengers who survived the sinking offered a vivid picture of how a trip to a resort island turned into catastrophe.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN, SU-HYUN LEE and JIHA HAM
item.media:description: Family members of passengers missing on the overturned ferry wept on Thursday at the port in Jindo.

item.title: India Ink: India’s Biggest Election Day
item.description: In the country’s fifth and largest phase of polling, 12 states went to vote, with more than one-fifth of the parliamentary seats up for grabs.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Lens Blog: Witness to History, Searching for Dignity
item.description: Twenty years after the genocide in Rwanda, David Turnley dug through his archives to confront not just ghastly images of atrocity, but also glimmers of human dignity and hope.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
World Press Picture of the Year
item.dc:creator: By JAMES ESTRIN
item.media:description: Rwandans fled with all they could carry in the midst of the panic of genocide and civil war, toward refugee camps in Zaire, Tanzania and Burundi.

item.title: Putin Asserts Right to Use Force in Eastern Ukraine
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin said he hoped invasion of what he called “new Russia” would not be necessary. He also said for the first time that Russian forces had been sent to Crimea.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:credit: Alexei Nikolsky/RIA Novosti Kremlin, via Associated Press
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia spoke during a televised question-and-answer show on Thursday.

item.title: India Ink: In Bihar, Economic Concerns Are Tied Up in Caste Politics
item.description: Development has become a central issue in this year’s elections, but voters are also mindful of how the state government makes decisions based on caste.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI
item.media:description: Nitish Kumar, center, chief minister of Bihar and a member of the Janata Dal (United) party, during a news conference in New Delhi on Feb. 25.

item.title: Russia Economy Worsens Even Before Sanctions Hit
item.description: With the country’s long-troubled economy teetering on the edge of recession, average Russians are feeling the pinch, even before the bite of Western sanctions over Crimea.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Ukrainian Forces Kill 3 Pro-Russian Demonstrators
item.description: The firefight in the city of Mariupol, the most lethal so far in eastern Ukraine, underscored the worsening security situation a day after government forces were humiliated by militants.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: A pro-Russian militant stood guard outside a police building in the eastern city of Slovyansk on Thursday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Talk About Your History, Oliver Stone Tells Chinese
item.description: The director Oliver Stone dropped a bombshell at the Beijing International Film Festival when he said that China had to face its history in order to stir creativity, a sensitive topic in a country where censorship is the norm.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Oliver Stone, with the Chinese actress Fan Bingbing, at the opening ceremony of the Beijing International Film Festival on Wednesday.

item.title: Letter From India: Votes Won by Feeling, Not Facts
item.description: Narendra Modi's rise would also emphasize the fact that the Indian voter condones a lot in politicians as long as he is enchanted by them.
item.dc:creator: By MANU JOSEPH

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Workers Strike at Shoe Factory Over Benefits Dispute
item.description: Workers at one of the world’s largest shoe manufacturers are on strike in the southern Chinese city of Dongguan in a dispute over benefits.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Striking workers gathered at Yue Yuen Industrial in Dongguan on Wednesday.
